sect1.title: Synopsis
sect1.para: Define properties for the tool, which can be used as parameters later in all scripts and can be configured when a workflow is set up.

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para: Properties are a means to let the user of the integrated tool configure some attributes when creating a workflow. For example, if your tool is able to run with multiple cores, you can define a key “numCores” and later add it as placeholder in your command execution script or pre/post execution script (e.g. “tool.exe ${prop:numCores}”). This key will then be shown in the properties tab in the workflow editor and the value for it can be defined there.
Properties have a display name that makes them more readable for others. Also, a default value can be defined, to provide some useful presettings.
It is not mandatory to define properties.

Since RCE 8.0 it is possible to define properties as placeholders. With this option, which is activated in the properties view of the tool component, the user can define that the value for the selected property is not defined while editing the workflow, but at workflow start.

While the use of properties allows a great amount of flexibility, they also easily lead to inadvertent security issues. Consider, e.g., a tool that copies some data to a configurable directory and removes that directory after its computation as part of cleanup. Malicious users may set the configuration directory to some vital system directory and cause the tool to remove that directory on termination. To prevent users from creating such security issues by accident, RCE does not allow the use of property values containing \", ASCII-characters in the range 0x00-0x1f, \\, /, \*, \?. Moreover, RCE prevents the use of % on Windows systems, and of ` and \$ on Linux systems.

If you would like to allow your users to supply a configuration file or a configuration directory, please add this file as an explicit input to the component. Other options include, e.g., fixing a "whitelist" of safe configuration options and allowing the user a choice of these configuration options via properties.

sect1.title: Groups
sect1.para: With groups you can categorize the properties and group properties for the same context. It is also possible to create a file for each group at runtime, which contains the keys and the respective values. These files will be located in the “Config” folder in a temporary directory with the name that you can also define here.
